title: Delete aws security group
body:
This PR prevents security group leaks.

Because we cannot start deleting security group before the instances are deleted, this increases teardown time.

It takes 48.812s to terminate a single AWS node after this PR. Before:  19.163s.

It takes 48.655s to terminate 4 AWS nodes after this PR. Before:  25.404s.

Actually with more nodes, the termination time does not go up, which is actually reasonable: the instance deletion latency hides the latency of the original `sky down`.

title: Sky storage becomes permission denied after training with imagenet
body:
I trained the imagenet dataset on sky storage with resnet model with the following yaml. After an epoch, I killed the model training and tried to launch another yaml on another cluster, but reading/writing files in the bucket becomes `Permission denied` (`ls` works properly).
```yaml
# Task 1
resources:
  cloud: aws
  accelerators: V100

file_mounts:
  /imagenet:
    name: sky-imagenet-data
    mode: MOUNT

setup: |
  git clone https://github.com/Michaelvll/examples.git
  cd ./examples/imagenet
  conda create -n imagenet python=3.9 -y
  conda activate imagenet
  conda install pytorch torchvision torchaudio cudatoolkit=11.3 -c pytorch -y
  pip install -r requirements.txt
  pip install wandb
  wandb login e2b8c727047ed1b4e28ac07e2c045faa416d6390

run: |
  conda activate imagenet
  mkdir -p /imagenet/checkpoints/ILSRC2012/imagenet/resnet18-s3

  cd ./examples/imagenet
  git pull
  python main.py -a resnet18 \
    --save-path /imagenet/checkpoints/ILSRC2012/imagenet/resnet18-s3 \
    --resume /imagenet/checkpoints/ILSRC2012/imagenet/resnet18-s3 \
    --workers 32 \
    /imagenet/datasets/ILSVRC2012/imagenet
```
```yaml
# Task 2
resources:
  cloud: aws
  accelerators: V100

file_mounts:
  /imagenet:
    name: sky-imagenet-data
    mode: MOUNT
```

PS: The behavior of the bucket is a bit weird. When I tried to tear down the cluster and re-launch, or wait for several hours and retry, the `Permission denied` problem still existed. However, after I remove the public access of the bucket using the s3 console, it seems the `Permission denied` disappear.

title: Problems in using LocalDockerBackend for debugging setup
body:
We've discussed using our local docker backend to resolve the difficulties in the setup, prior to provisioning (see #670 and this [gist](https://gist.github.com/concretevitamin/51e82f8b210ed7b905de20eb95bc8d6d)). As a preliminary investigation, I tried to use it for some example projects and identified the following problems:

0. The Docker build time on a laptop can be non-negligible. On my M1 Macbook Air, `pip install torch` alone (inside a container) takes 4 minutes. `conda install -c conda-forge cupy` alone takes 6 minutes. The installation time was not a big issue for cloud instances because they usually have good CPUs and network bandwidth. But for laptops, installation can take a significant amount of time, and thus the docker build time can be quite annoying to users.

1. Currently, Sky does not make the best use of the Docker cache. It's because the setup commands are not directly exposed to docker; our Dockerfile does `RUN ./sky/sky_setup.sh` and `sky_setup.sh` runs all the user-level setup commands. Thus, any change in the user setup commands will restart the docker build from scratch. I believe this can be solved by exposing the raw commands to Dockerfile.

2. Even if the above problem is solved, the Docker cache may not be effectively utilized because of workdir syncing. A typical sky-generated Dockerfile will be like this:
```Dockerfile
# workdir sync
COPY sky_workdir /sky_workdir/
WORKDIR /sky_workdir/
# Do file mounts
...
# Run user setup commands below
RUN apt-get install ...
RUN conda create -n ...
RUN pip install -r requirements.txt
```
In such a case, every time the user modifies a file in workdir (e.g., `requirements.txt`) for debugging setup, docker will restart the build from the COPY instruction and will not skip `apt-get install` nor `pip install`.

3. The setup experience can be different in a cloud and on a laptop, due to the dependencies on NVIDIA libraries. In my experience, `pip install cupy` worked well on cloud GPU instances, but not on the local docker backend. This was because the `pip install cupy` requires CUDA toolkits to be installed in the system (or docker image). Using NVIDIA containers was not a solution, because they only support Linux distributions ([link](https://docs.nvidia.com/datacenter/cloud-native/container-toolkit/install-guide.html#platform-requirements)).

4. Supporting `git clone` inside a container can be tricky.

title: Use `pipreqs` to simplify setup in some scenarios
body:
https://github.com/bndr/pipreqs is a package to automatically find out what python packages are imported, thus needed, by a code base. Useful if a requirements.txt doesn't already exist.  This may help us set some users up either programmatically or manually.

---

I tried it on Balsa in a fresh conda env (without any dependencies): 
```
» pipreqs . --print
``` 

Most seem reasonable except the first line that is invalid, `absl==0.0`.

title: Shared default security group for AWS
body: This avoids creating too many security groups for our users.

title: Support asynchronous setup and file_mounts
body:
Our current setup and file_mounts require the user's laptop to have an `ssh` connection with the cluster, which means the setup or file_mounts will be stopped if the user stop the laptop. When the setup takes a long time, it is easy for the user to fail the setup.

Workaround: place setup in the run section.

title: Specify region in resources
body:
Closes #695. Added a region field in the `Resources`.

BEHAVIOR CHANGE:
1. If a cluster is in INIT mode and re-launched, the failover will be disabled, i.e. only try to launch it on the previously failed region. 
  Previous: If a cluster is in INIT mode and re-launched, the failover will be enabled within a cloud, i.e. try to failover on the previously failed cloud. 
  Comment: this does not affect much of the normal use case, as our cluster is unlikely to be in `INIT` mode unless:
      1. the user ctrl-C during the `ray up`
      1. our ray yaml file has some bug.

Tested:
- [x] Backward compatibility: `sky launch -c min ./examples/minimal.yaml` with the previous version. `sky status/sky exec/sky launch` with the current version.
- [x] `sky launch -c min --region us-west-2 ./examples/minimal.yaml`, `sky exec min ./examples/minimal.yaml`
- [x] `sky launch -c min --region us-west-2 ./examples/minimal.yaml`, `sky exec min ./examples/minimal.yaml` with `resources: region: us-east-1`. Failed as expected.
- [x] `sky launch -c min --region us-west-2 ./examples/minimal.yaml`, `sky launch -c min --region us-west-1 ./examples/minimal.yaml`. Failed as expected.
- [x] `tests/run_smoke_tests.sh`

title: Change default gpu from K80 to T4
body:
As discussed in https://github.com/sky-proj/sky/issues/700, T4 seems to be a better choice as the default gpu node. Please comment below if you have any additional thoughts.

Copied from the discussion.
> Speaking of the default gpu node type, should we consider changing it to g4dn.xlarge? It can be cheaper (0.900 vs 0.526, tho host memory size is smaller) and T4 is a newer generation than K80. (remember that we had to choose images with older nvidia driver in order to support K80). It supports mixed precision and seems to be more cost efficient than K80 ([details here](https://cloud.google.com/blog/products/ai-machine-learning/your-ml-workloads-cheaper-and-faster-with-the-latest-gpus)).

A possible issue is that `T4:1` requirement is satisfied by many VM instances on clouds so the candidate list is longer. not sure if users would like it or not.

Before:
```
(sky) weichiang@blaze:~/repos/sky$ sky gpunode
I 04-05 00:01:32 optimizer.py:601] Optimizer - plan minimizing cost
I 04-05 00:01:32 optimizer.py:613] Estimated cost: ~$0.2/hr
I 04-05 00:01:32 optimizer.py:628] 
I 04-05 00:01:32 optimizer.py:628] TASK     BEST_RESOURCE
I 04-05 00:01:32 optimizer.py:628] gpunode  Azure(Standard_NC6_Promo, {'K80': 1})
I 04-05 00:01:32 optimizer.py:628] 
I 04-05 00:01:32 optimizer.py:648] Considered resources -> cost ($)
I 04-05 00:01:32 optimizer.py:649] {Azure(Standard_NC6_Promo, {'K80': 1}): 0.22,
I 04-05 00:01:32 optimizer.py:649]  AWS(p2.xlarge, {'K80': 1}): 0.9,
I 04-05 00:01:32 optimizer.py:649]  GCP(n1-highmem-8, {'K80': 1}): 0.92}
I 04-05 00:01:32 optimizer.py:649] 
I 04-05 00:01:32 optimizer.py:665] Multiple Azure instances satisfy K80:1. The cheapest Azure(Standard_NC6_Promo, {'K80': 1}) is considered among:
I 04-05 00:01:32 optimizer.py:665] ['Standard_NC6_Promo', 'Standard_NC6'].
I 04-05 00:01:32 optimizer.py:665] 
I 04-05 00:01:32 optimizer.py:671] To list more details, run 'sky show-gpus K80'.
```

After:
```
(sky) weichiang@blaze:~/repos/sky$ sky gpunode
I 04-05 00:00:48 optimizer.py:601] Optimizer - plan minimizing cost
I 04-05 00:00:48 optimizer.py:613] Estimated cost: ~$0.5/hr
I 04-05 00:00:48 optimizer.py:628] 
I 04-05 00:00:48 optimizer.py:628] TASK     BEST_RESOURCE
I 04-05 00:00:48 optimizer.py:628] gpunode  AWS(g4dn.xlarge, {'T4': 1})
I 04-05 00:00:48 optimizer.py:628] 
I 04-05 00:00:48 optimizer.py:648] Considered resources -> cost ($)
I 04-05 00:00:48 optimizer.py:649] {GCP(n1-highmem-8, {'T4': 1}): 0.82,
I 04-05 00:00:48 optimizer.py:649]  Azure(Standard_NC4as_T4_v3, {'T4': 1}): 0.63,
I 04-05 00:00:48 optimizer.py:649]  AWS(g4dn.xlarge, {'T4': 1}): 0.53}
I 04-05 00:00:48 optimizer.py:649] 
I 04-05 00:00:48 optimizer.py:665] Multiple AWS instances satisfy T4:1. The cheapest AWS(g4dn.xlarge, {'T4': 1}) is considered among:
I 04-05 00:00:48 optimizer.py:665] ['g4dn.xlarge', 'g4dn.2xlarge', 'g4dn.4xlarge', 'g4dn.8xlarge', 'g4dn.16xlarge'].
I 04-05 00:00:48 optimizer.py:665] 
I 04-05 00:00:48 optimizer.py:665] Multiple Azure instances satisfy T4:1. The cheapest Azure(Standard_NC4as_T4_v3, {'T4': 1}) is considered among:
I 04-05 00:00:48 optimizer.py:665] ['Standard_NC4as_T4_v3', 'Standard_NC8as_T4_v3', 'Standard_NC16as_T4_v3'].
I 04-05 00:00:48 optimizer.py:665] 
I 04-05 00:00:48 optimizer.py:671] To list more details, run 'sky show-gpus T4'.
```

title: Backward compatibility tests on states in DB
body:
In the latest storage [PR](https://github.com/sky-proj/sky/pull/658/) we renamed some states of buckets (e.g., `DONE` to `READY`)
https://github.com/sky-proj/sky/pull/658/files#diff-db4566a60e392e4076a1a2bc4eaa56e57c4c2a060b23ff98e8b7b71e3e3d35f1L131

This caused a backward compatibility issue to `sky storage ls` to the buckets I created earlier and I had to manually clean up storage table in DB and remove the buckets myself.
```
(sky) weichiang@blaze:~/repos$ sky storage ls              
Traceback (most recent call last):                                   
  File "/data/weichiang/miniconda3/envs/sky/bin/sky", line 33, in <module> 
    sys.exit(load_entry_point('sky', 'console_scripts', 'sky')())        
  File "/data/weichiang/miniconda3/envs/sky/lib/python3.8/site-packages/click/core.py", line 1137, in __call__
    return self.main(*args, **kwargs)                      
  File "/data/weichiang/miniconda3/envs/sky/lib/python3.8/site-packages/click/core.py", line 1062, in main
    rv = self.invoke(ctx)                                       
  File "/data/weichiang/miniconda3/envs/sky/lib/python3.8/site-packages/click/core.py", line 1668, in invoke
    return _process_result(sub_ctx.command.invoke(sub_ctx))    
  File "/data/weichiang/miniconda3/envs/sky/lib/python3.8/site-packages/click/core.py", line 1668, in invoke
    return _process_result(sub_ctx.command.invoke(sub_ctx))
  File "/data/weichiang/miniconda3/envs/sky/lib/python3.8/site-packages/click/core.py", line 1404, in invoke
    return ctx.invoke(self.callback, **ctx.params)
  File "/data/weichiang/miniconda3/envs/sky/lib/python3.8/site-packages/click/core.py", line 763, in invoke
    return __callback(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/home/eecs/weichiang/repos/sky/sky/cli.py", line 1846, in storage_ls
    storage_stat = global_user_state.get_storage()
  File "/home/eecs/weichiang/repos/sky/sky/global_user_state.py", line 371, in get_storage
    'status': StorageStatus[status],
  File "/data/weichiang/miniconda3/envs/sky/lib/python3.8/enum.py", line 387, in __getitem__
    return cls._member_map_[name]
KeyError: 'DONE'
```
Should we add backward compatibility tests on states (of cluster/storage) stored in DB to avoid users hitting such errors after upgrading Sky?
One simple test would be to use previous version of Sky to run smoke tests and later update Sky. All sky commands still need to function normally.

title: UX: `sky status` should hint about --refresh if there are clusters with autostop scheduled
body:
Users may see an UP cluster with AUTOSTOP column set, and are confused by it "why is it still showing as UP even though the instance has stopped"?

Proposal:
- Detect if `sky status` shows any UP cluster with AUTOSTOP scheduled 
- If so, output a hint line at the bottom, along the lines of "You have X clusters with autostop scheduled. Refresh statuses with: `sky status --refresh`."

title: Autostop should consider the setup as not idle
body: Our autostop will only consider the run section, but the setup section can take very long and the cluster can be stopped even if the setup is still running.

body:
If a cluster is autostopped and the `sky status --refresh` is not called, the `sky start` will show the following:
```
sky start dementrock-sky-eval
Cluster dementrock-sky-eval already has status UP.
```

title: Fix optimizer messages
body:
This PR closes #700

The fixed optimizer will 
* skip the head message (`Optimizer - plan minimizing cost`) if the search space is trivial, and
* print hourly cost when the DAG consists of a task that does not have a time estimator and does not involve any data egress.

NOTE: `sky gpunode` still prints the header message because there are three candidates (each for three cloud vendors).
```
$ sky gpunode
I 04-04 19:09:08 optimizer.py:601] Optimizer - plan minimizing cost
I 04-04 19:09:08 optimizer.py:613] Estimated hourly cost: ~$0.2/hr
I 04-04 19:09:08 optimizer.py:628] 
I 04-04 19:09:08 optimizer.py:628] TASK     BEST_RESOURCE
I 04-04 19:09:08 optimizer.py:628] gpunode  Azure(Standard_NC6_Promo, {'K80': 1})
I 04-04 19:09:08 optimizer.py:628] 
I 04-04 19:09:08 optimizer.py:648] Considered resources -> cost ($)
I 04-04 19:09:08 optimizer.py:649] {GCP(n1-highmem-8, {'K80': 1}): 0.92,
I 04-04 19:09:08 optimizer.py:649]  AWS(p2.xlarge, {'K80': 1}): 0.9,
I 04-04 19:09:08 optimizer.py:649]  Azure(Standard_NC6_Promo, {'K80': 1}): 0.22}
I 04-04 19:09:08 optimizer.py:649] 
I 04-04 19:09:08 optimizer.py:665] Multiple Azure instances satisfy K80:1. The cheapest Azure(Standard_NC6_Promo, {'K80': 1}) is considered among:
I 04-04 19:09:08 optimizer.py:665] ['Standard_NC6_Promo', 'Standard_NC6'].
I 04-04 19:09:08 optimizer.py:665]
```

On the other hand, `sky gpunode --cloud aws` skips the message (`Optimizer - plan minimizing cost`) since the candidate instance type is unique.
```
$ sky gpunode --cloud aws
I 04-04 19:04:58 optimizer.py:613] Estimated hourly cost: ~$0.9/hr
I 04-04 19:04:58 optimizer.py:628] 
I 04-04 19:04:58 optimizer.py:628] TASK     BEST_RESOURCE
I 04-04 19:04:58 optimizer.py:628] gpunode  AWS(p2.xlarge, {'K80': 1})
I 04-04 19:04:58 optimizer.py:628]
```

title: Strorage: COPY mode copies entire bucket even if only a subdir is requested
body:
The following copies the entire bucket:

Switching to the vanilla version works as expected

title: Storage: Goofys OOM-killed when mounting/using a big bucket
body:
User report:

I was trying out the s3 file system mount. With some config like:
```
file_mounts:
  /data/xxx:
    source: s3://some-giant-bucket
    mode: MOUNT
```
This worked ok initially and I was able to start a training job and run initialization of the dataloader. However half way through I’m starting to get errors like
```
OSError: [Errno 107] Transport endpoint is not connected: '/data/xxx/....json'
```
And if I check the mounted folder it’s gone (also gone in df -h). When I first started the instance it was OK though.

from syslog, looks like goofys ran out of memory lol
```
Apr  4 12:03:28 ip-172-16-29-213 kernel: [ 2497.250427] oom-kill:constraint=CONSTRAINT_NONE,nodemask=(null),cpuset=/,mems_allowed=0,global_oom,task_memcg=/user.slice/user-1000.slice/session-11.scope,task=goofys,pid=26769,uid=1000
Apr  4 12:03:28 ip-172-16-29-213 kernel: [ 2497.250468] Out of memory: Killed process 26769 (goofys) total-vm:9484132kB, anon-rss:9350624kB, file-rss:0kB, shmem-rss:0kB, UI
```
using a g4dn.xlarge currently.

Usage pattern
- some stats of a particular subfolder of this bucket that we’re loading data from. 
  - 1.9M total objects, total size 841GB
- Lots of small files, and at the beginning of training we have some directory listing commands that seems to make the goofys climb up in memory usage.
- there might be some concurrent operations after the directory listing steps too for data loading.
------

TODO: reproduce, investigate, mitigate?

title: UX: progress bar for stopping clusters may be confusing if skipping over certain clusters
body:
User: the behavior of “stopping” a cluster is a bit weird; progress bar shows 100% but the cluster wasn’t actually stopped? (using sky down worked)
```
(base) MacBook-Pro-2:cloud_cluster_eval dementrock$ sky stop --all
Stopping 1 cluster: sky-eval. Proceed? [Y/n]: y
Stopping cluster sky-eval... skipped.
  The spot instances may lose attached volumes.
  To terminate the cluster, run: sky down sky-eval
Stopping 1 cluster ━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━ 100% 0:00:00
```

---

This happened because we skip over a spot instance cluster.

We may want to 
- change the "100%" count?
- change `The spot instances may lose attached volumes.` to something clearer, e.g., `Stopping spot instances is not supported as the attached disks will be lost.`
- change `To terminate the cluster` to add "...instead"?

title: Story for users to save the code persistently when editing on a spot instance
body: We lack a *good* story for users that edit code on a spot instance. The spot VM can die anytime, so how is the code progress going to be saved? Not that in this case, the user does *not* want to use the workdir. One suggested story -- use mounted storage to save the code -- has the following issue for jupyterlab - a lot of “notebook changed” messages will be printed Actions for us: - [ ] investigate how to make the suggested story work for jupyterlab - [ ] Verify the suggested story works for VSCode (non-jupyterlab) - [ ] is there an alternative story?

title: Prompt Before Storage Initialization for `sky launch`
body:
Fixes #681. The bug is that when the YAML file contains Storage, `sky launch -c hello myyaml.yml` will uploading contents/connect to Storage bucket before the prompt `Launching a new cluster. Proceed? [Y/n]:`.

## Tests

```
resources:
  cloud: aws

num_nodes: 1  

workdir: .

file_mounts:
  /datasets-storage:
    name: mluo-2022
    source: .

setup: |
  echo "here"
  echo "export TEST_VAR=test" >> ~/.bashrc

run: |
  if [[ -z "${TEST_VAR}" ]]; then
    echo "TEST_VAR is not set"
    exit 1
  else
    echo "TEST_VAR is set to ${TEST_VAR}"
  fi

  if [[ -d ~/sky_workdir/sky ]]; then
    echo "~/sky_workdir/sky exists"
  else
    echo "~/sky_workdir/sky does not exist"
    exit 1
  fi

  echo NODE ID: $SKY_NODE_RANK
  echo NODE IPS: "$SKY_NODE_IPS"
  worker_addr=`echo "$SKY_NODE_IPS" | sed -n 2p`
  echo Worker IP: $worker_addr
```

title: Storage exception hierarchy is too complex
body:
_Originally posted by @concretevitamin in https://github.com/sky-proj/sky/pull/658#discussion_r838758189_

It's hard to keep track of too many errors, and the hierarchy also makes things harder (e.g., if I'm a developer, which do I throw or catch)?  How about moving these to our `sky/exceptions.py` and simplifying a bit / flattening the hierarchy? (See styleguide below)

```python
# exceptions.py:

class StorageInvalidSpecError(ValueError):
    """Construction-time errors: invalid source, name, or mode."""
    pass


class StorageInitError(RuntimeError):  # FIXME: I don't see any usage of this? ok to remove?
    # Error raised when Initialization fails - either due to permissions,
    # unavailable name, or other reasons.
    pass


class StorageBucketCreateError(RuntimeError):
    # Error raised when bucket creation fails.
    pass


class StorageBucketGetError(RuntimeError):
    # Error raised if attempt to fetch an existing bucket fails.
    pass
```
For StorageInvalidSpecError, the unit tests can use string messages to check which cases occur (tradeoff). Wdyt?

---

Styleguide refs:
- Error messages (such as: message strings on exceptions like ValueError, or messages shown to the user) should follow three guidelines: ... They should allow simple automated processing (e.g. grepping). https://google.github.io/styleguide/pyguide.html#3102-error-messages
- Make use of built-in exception classes when it makes sense. For example, raise a ValueError to indicate a programming mistake like a violated precondition (such as if you were passed a negative number but required a positive one).
- Libraries or packages may define their own exceptions. When doing so they must inherit from an existing exception class. Exception names should end in Error and should not introduce repetition (foo.FooError). https://google.github.io/styleguide/pyguide.html#244-decision

title: UX: Change the default behavior of `sky exec -- inline cmd` to submit job
body:
The current default behavior of inline cmd without specifying the GPU requirements is the same as `ssh -c cmd`, and will not submit the task to the job queue. It is different from any other behaviors of `sky exec` and `sky launch`. It may cause confusion for the users, e.g. Daniel used the inline command to run his training job without specifying the GPU requirement, and found the ctrl-c did not kill the job entirely.

Proposal:
1. Submit all commands run with `sky exec` to the job queue.
2. For interactive usage (e.g. `gpustat` or `htop`), ask the user to `ssh` into the cluster.

Pros:
1. The behavior of all `sky exec` will be consistent without confusion.
2. We can make the user be used to the `sky exec` and `sky cancel` pipeline, without finding different behaviors when not specifying the `--gpus`. Also, we can force the user to utilize the `sky cancel` which will kill the processes without leaving defunct processes (compared to ctrl-c).
3. Asking the user to do any interactive usage by `ssh` into the cluster, so that we can let the user take the responsibility for those processes that are not killed entirely caused by ctrl-c (e.g. PyTorch DataParallel).

Cons:
1. Simple commands will have extra overheads if they are executed with `sky exec`. (It can be resolved by asking the user to ssh into the cluster and run those commands)

Sometimes I accidentally type `num_workers: 2` instead of `num_nodes: 2` in a sky YAML. `num_workers: 2` silently succeeds, and the user is left wondering why only 1 node was spun up.

Some users may not have their git SSH key added to their local SSH agent which is necessary for automatic agent forwarding (and easy cloning of private repos) on the remote VM. We should make it obvious in the documentation how to set this up with:
```
eval $(ssh-agent -s)
ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_rsa
```
We can do something like: https://docs.github.com/en/authentication/connecting-to-github-with-ssh/generating-a-new-ssh-key-and-adding-it-to-the-ssh-agent

This came up in Justin's session.

title: Fix Repeating IP in SSH Config
body:
## Description

The edge case is the following. If SSH Config already has `Host hello` (from user's prior experiments prior to installing/using Sky) and the user runs `sky launch -c hello examples/env_check.yaml`, Sky will add 
```
# Added by sky (use `sky stop/down hello` to remove)
Host 18.215.241.153
  HostName 18.215.241.153
  User ubuntu
  IdentityFile /Users/michaelluo/.ssh/sky-key
  IdentitiesOnly yes
  ForwardAgent yes
  StrictHostKeyChecking no
  Port 22
```
However, if `sky launch -c hello examples/env_check.yaml` is run multiple times, the above block is added multiple times to the config file. This is due to the fact that there is no check for this case.

## Tests

Step 1: Add this block to the Config file.
```
# Fake SSH Config
Host hallo
  HostName 59.152.136.89
  User ubuntu
  IdentityFile /Users/michaelluo/.ssh/sky-key
  IdentitiesOnly yes
  ForwardAgent yes
  StrictHostKeyChecking no
  Port 22
```
Step 2: Run `sky launch -c examples/env_check.yaml`

Step 3: Random Sky up and Sky downs

title: Fix GCP Lock Bug
body:
## Description

Solves #629. Launching a GCP instance and having `sudo apt/apt-get install XYZ` will error out due to lock being held by DPKG process.

Unlike in AWS or Azure, GCP does not have `lsof` or `fuser`, so a more brute force method is used to identify the process that is holding the lock: 
`sudo kill -9  'sudo find /proc/*/fd -ls | grep /var/lib/dpkg/lock-frontend | grep -oP '/proc/\d+' | tail -n 1 | grep -oP '\d+'' || true;`
This line above goes through the process folder and through a bunch of regex, finds the process ID that is holding the lock. 


Last but not least, restarting DPKG has errors on GCP, and the work around is uninstalling and reinstalling `google-cloud-sdk`.

## Test
The following YAML passes without erorrs:
```
name: apt-lock-bug
resources:
  cloud: gcp
  instance_type: n1-highmem-2
setup: |
  sudo apt install cargo
  sudo apt-get install libosmesa6-dev
```

title: Storage mounting
body:
This PR implements sky storage mounting, which allows us to directly mount S3/GCS buckets without having to copy their contents. This also enables writing to mounts, effectively allowing users to provision an infinitely scaling networked file system shared among worker nodes.

More details are in the [proposal](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1uVNTWk44lvzPFTr9flfPZrs-sT6fiKlqnAPROprwEmU/).

# Major changes

## `sky.Storage`
* Added object store mounting support for Store objects. 
* Removed deprecated storage/storage_mount YAML API.
* Add `StorageError` family of exceptions for more effective error handling.
* Added distributed training example with automatic checkpointing and restore (thanks @michaelzhiluo and @michaelvll)


## Validation logic
* All storage objects must now satisfy the following validation logic:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4416605/160348903-38743796-17d3-480c-a51a-7694deac299f.png)
* Validation logic moved from from_yaml to Storage object.

## Interaction with Global User State
* Only objects managed by sky are now added to the global user state. 
* When loading from `global_user_state`, self.source no longer needs to match the source in global_user_state.
* Added a `sync_on_reconstruction` flag to Storage class to specify whether to (re)upload source when the Storage object is reconstructed from `global_user_state` or not. Useful to set this to False when e.g. when reconstructing for deletion.


## Refactoring
* Refactored `Storage.get_or_copy_to_s3/gcs()` to `.add_store(StoreType.S3/GCS)`
* Rename `force_stores` to `store` in YAML and change it from List[str] to str (single store only).
* Rename `StorageType` to `StoreType`
* Removed unused arg `cloud_to_remote_file_mounts` in `backend.sync_file_mounts()` and added `storage_mounts` as an arg
* Refactor cloud_vm_ray_backend.sync_file_mounts() to also execute storage mounts.
* Removed deprecated storage API from YAML

## TODO:
- [x] Add tests for sky.Storage
- [x] Add more examples (distributed counting example to demonstrate the use of shared FS)
- [x] Update documentation
- [ ] GCS Mounting with gcsfuse (separate PR)
- [ ] `sky storage mount` for local mounting on laptop (separate PR)


## Tested:
- [x] Smoke tests
- [x] New storage tests

title: [100 jobs] Abnormal failover leading to duplicate instances
body:
Milestone "100 jobs": Launch 100 jobs, each taking its own cluster.

```bash
#!/bin/bash
set -ex
for i in $(seq 100); do
    sky launch -y -d --cloud=aws -c node-"$i" --gpus=K80 >node-"$i".log 2>&1 -- "gpustat; echo node $i"  &
    sleep 2
done
wait
sky autostop --all
```

----

Console shows all 90 VMs are Running.  However, sky status shows ~19 UP (successfully finished the command), the rest all INIT (failed).  

One type of failures is weird:
```
I 03-27 11:30:08 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:952] Launching on AWS us-east-1 (us-east-1a,us-east-1b,us-east-1c,us-east-1d,us-east-1e,us-east-1f)
I 03-27 11:31:29 log_lib.py:37] Head node is up.
W 03-27 11:33:09 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:542] Got error(s) in all zones of us-east-1:
W 03-27 11:33:09 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:544]   2022-03-27 11:30:23,714 WARN node_provider.py:444 -- create_instances: Attempt failed with An error occurred (InsufficientInstanceCapacity) when calling the RunInstances operation (reached max retries: 0): We currently do not have sufficient p2.xlarge capacity in the Availability Zone you requested (us-east-1a). Our system will be working on provisioning additional capacity. You can currently get p2.xlarge capacity by not specifying an Availability Zone in your request or choosing us-east-1b, us-east-1c, us-east-1d, us-east-1e., retrying.
I 03-27 11:36:38 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:952] Launching on AWS us-east-2 (us-east-2a,us-east-2b,us-east-2c)
W 03-27 11:36:54 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:542] Got error(s) in all zones of us-east-2:
...
I 03-27 11:37:11 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:535] ====== stderr ======
2022-03-27 11:37:01,945 INFO util.py:282 -- setting max workers for head node type to 0
2022-03-27 11:37:11,008 PANIC config.py:665 -- Failed to create security group
```
- [x] (Solved by #661)  It shows us-east-1a failed. Console shows this node is launched in us-east-1b.  So we should not have failed over to us-east-2.
- [ ] After “failing over” to us-east-2, `Failed to create security group` shown.  This error happens again (see the 1st comment below).

- [x] (Solved by #657) Another type of failures is wheel builds -- even with locking already added -- overwrite each other.  15 nodes have this failure.
```
file has vanished: "/var/folders/8f/56gzvwkd3n3293xjlrztr6600000gp/T/sky_wheels_zongheng/sky.egg-info/top_level.txt"
...
rsync warning: some files vanished before they could be transferred (code 24) at /AppleInternal/BuildRoot/Library/Caches/com.apple.xbs/Sources/rsync/rsync-54.
120.1/rsync/main.c(996) [sender=2.6.9]
```

- [x] (No longer triggers with #657 merged ) Final result is resource leak:  Console shows duplicate nodes launched in 3 regions: east-1 (90), east-2 (19), west-2 (51).   There should be in total 90 instances according to the script.

- [ ] Lots of runs print `create_instances: Attempt failed with An error occurred (RequestLimitExceeded) when calling the RunInstances operation (reached max retries: 0): Request limit exceeded., retrying.`.  We should add randomized backoff, potentially.


- [ ] (Orthogonal/related) When launching 90 in parallel, laptop will be pretty oversubscribed.  To solve this we need async provisioning / send these launches to a service (can be a skylet server running locally that queues these provisioning requests).

- [x] (Mitigated by #731 as we use a few shared SGs now) (Orthogonal/related) ray down doesn't delete the security groups created. My num security group limit is 2500 per region, and I now have 200-400 SGs per region.

- [ ] sqlite3.OperationalError: database is locked

title: Auto stop for cluster
body:
This PR enables the auto-stopping feature for the clusters. [Design Doc](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1nBoT9k7jcDcXVUkcpYFmp0nikaRV-aDe2ZufVWIgOVA/edit#)

Main Changes:
1. `sky autostop cluster-name -i 30`, auto-stop the cluster after 30 minutes without activities.
2. Refactor the skylet daemon with events.
3. Add autostop event in skylet.
4. Indicate the auto stop status in `sky status`
5. Update the status of the cluster autostopped

New API:
1. `sky autostop cluster_name1 cluster_name2`: cluster will stop as soon as the cluster is idle
2. `sky autostop cluster_name1 cluster_name2 -i t`: cluster will stop after t minutes of inactivity.
3.  `sky autostop cluster_name1 cluster_name2 --cancel`: cancel the autostop on the cluster_name.
4. `sky status --refresh`: refresh the status for auto-stopped cluster.

Problem:
1. `sky status` will be slower if one of the clusters set autostop.
```
(sky-dev) ➜  sky-experiment-dev (auto-stop) time sky status                                                            
NAME               LAUNCHED     RESOURCES                 STATUS  AUTOSTOP  COMMAND                                    
test-auto-azure-4  21 mins ago  4x Azure(Standard_D8_v4)  INIT    -         sky launch -c test-auto-azure-4 ...        
test-auto-4        15 mins ago  4x GCP(n1-highmem-8)      UP      -         sky launch -c test-auto-4 --cloud gcp ...  
sky status  1.31s user 0.33s system 213% cpu 0.767 total

(sky-dev) ➜  sky-experiment-dev (auto-stop) time sky status --refresh
NAME               LAUNCHED     RESOURCES                 STATUS  AUTOSTOP  COMMAND                                    
test-auto-azure-4  21 mins ago  4x Azure(Standard_D8_v4)  INIT    -         sky launch -c test-auto-azure-4 ...        
test-auto-4        15 mins ago  4x GCP(n1-highmem-8)      UP      0 min     sky launch -c test-auto-4 --cloud gcp ...  
sky status  3.42s user 0.84s system 97% cpu 4.369 total
```
5. `sky status` will be set to STOPPED before all the nodes are stopped. (expected)

TODO:

title: [Documentation] AWS Access ID Page
body:
For Sky installation, some users may have not fully setup AWS prior to using Sky. Specifically, users need to know how to get AWS Access Key ID and the Secret Access Key to set up AWS.

To remedy this, in our documentation, we should mention and link: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/powershell/latest/userguide/pstools-appendix-sign-up.html , so the user knows how to retrieve these keys from AWS console.

title: [Documentation] Installation Docs should include `conda create ...`
body:
## Description

Not all users are familiar with Conda semantics, especially when creating a new conda env on local or in the remote environment (e.g. our Resnet example). Hence, adding documentation for `conda create -n sky python=3.9` is suggested.

title: [Documentation] Add `file_mounts` to DNN Training Example
body:
## Description

Tianjun's use case involves RL and using Mujoco, a complicated library for RL simulation that is quite difficult to setup. This requires using file mounts. This also raises the need to add `file_mounts` to the DNN training example so the user knows what to do in these use cases.

title: [Setup] SSH Config Bug, Repeating IPs
body:
## Description

In a nutshell, if clustername `hello` already exists, if you launch `sky launch -c hello x.yml`, Sky will add 
```
Host 59.152.136.89
  HostName 59.152.136.89
  User ubuntu
  IdentityFile /Users/michaelluo/.ssh/sky-key
  IdentitiesOnly yes
  ForwardAgent yes
  StrictHostKeyChecking no
  Port 22
```
to the `~/.ssh/config` folder. However, if `sky launch -c hello x.yml` is ran multiple times, the above block will be added again each time, resulting in duplicate blocks.

## Fix

I'll fix it.

title: [Setup] Conda YAML File - Conflicting and Missing Dependencies
body:
## Description

To move his environment from `blaze` to the setup script, Tianjun exported his current environment with `conda env export > environment.yml`. Later when he tried to build the environment from `enviornment.yaml` via `conda create -f environment.yml`, it failed. 

It failed due to two reasons,
1) There were conflicting dependencies. Conda could not find a the right versions that matched the specifications in the YAML file. More described here: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/58216917/create-conda-environment-found-conflicts-when-solving-environment-and-findi

2) There were missing dependencies. After Tianjun and co. installed Mujoco, there were missing package dependencies which were not installed via Conda (via `apt-get` package manager), such as `patchelf`,  `libosmesa-dev`, `libglew-dev`.

## Fix

?

title: [Setup] `sky_workdir` Structure
body:
## Description

Related to #388. When Tianjun tried to set his environment variables and setup his work directory, these factors depended on the work directory being named `nce_spede`.

This, however, conflicts with how Sky treats a work directory. If a work directory is `~/my_workdirectory/*`, then on remote, Sky would move the contents to `~/sky_workdir/*`. This kills the information fo the work directory name ` my_workdirectory`.

So far, this affected all our users. According to Romil,

From kevin's doc: "Needed prompt to find his files in ‘sky_workdir’ when he ssh’d into his vm."

From Daniel's doc: "sky_workdir being named sky_workdir prevents people from custom installing their packages (e.g. pip install -e) #388 “This is not what I expected to happen, when I say my workdir is qm9 I expect the workdir to be named qm9 on the cluster, not in sky_workdir”"

## Fix

There was a good discussion in #388. Continuing off of that discussion, some possible suggestions were
1) Do `~/sky_workdir/my_workdirectory`
2) Symlink the absolute path `/Users/michaelluo/my_workdirectory` to `~/sky_workdir` on remote
